title: Zauberland, Linbury Theatre, review: Schumann's song-cycle turned into an intriguing but pretentious pantomime
text:
If you read the synopsis printed in the programme for this strange event, you will be led to expect the tale of a pregnant Syrian woman who leaves her family in Syria to migrate to Germany and continue her career as a classical singer. She has a dream in which singing Schumann’s song-cycle Dichterliebe is mixed up with memories of her life in Aleppo and her journey west. But someone whose eyes have not alighted on this explanation might interpret what they see rather differently, even if the frame and reference point is clearly the sort of austere classical recital favoured by the Wigmore Hall.

Behind the game is Katie Mitchell, the most stylistically mannered of contemporary “auteur” directors,...
description: If you read the synopsis printed in the programme for this strange event, you will be led to expect the tale of a pregnant Syrian woman who leaves her family in Syria to migrate to Germany and continue her career as a classical singer.
